awd_titl_txt: RUI: Higher Structures in Stable, Equivariant, and Motivic Homotopy Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This research investigates the interface between three branches of contemporary mathematics:  higher categories, homotopy theory, and algebraic geometry.  Loosely speaking, these subjects study structure, deformations, and polynomials, respectively.  The projects undertaken via this award link these concepts in novel ways, seeking to expose new theorems.  The Principal Investigors will also support the participation of a diverse group of undergraduate students in their research by organizing summer research groups and leading senior theses related to these projects.

The PIs' approach to their research program is five-fold.  First, they will jointly study the fashion in which spectral Mackey functors of an absolute Galois group map to "spectral Gysin functors" (constructed from Garkusha-Panin-Voevodksy's theory of framed correspondences) which model motivic spectra.  Second, they will study the eta-periodic motivic sphere spectrum via connective Witt K-theory.  Third, they will explicate further structure in the Balmer spectrum of the stable motivic homotopy category via comodules over the Lazard Hopf algebroid.  Fourth, they will construct equivariant infinite loop space machines which handle pairings of genuine G-permutative categories.  And finally, they will study the homotopy theory of Picard 2-groupoids and stable 2-types, and the interaction between the two.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

During the report submission period, the PIs and their collaborators completed research leading to the publication of one article and submission of two further articles. All of these projects sprang out of our summer 2020 electronic Collaborative Mathematics Research Group (eCMRG), in which the PIs and five Reed College undergraduates spent eight weeks researching equivariant homotopy theory and transfer systems. Our work revealed a surprising correspondence between transfer systems and weak factorization systems, which we exploited to (a) produce a duality on transfer systems and (b) enumerate model structures on finite chains. We also (c) enumerated saturated transfer systems on a new family of groups and (d) proved Rubin's saturation conjecture for cyclic groups of order pqn for p, q distinct primes.

This work is especially exciting in that it establishes new methods for enumerating model structures on finite categories, a field we dub homotopical combinatorics. A model structure on a category C consists of data (classes of fibrations, cofibrations, and weak equivalences) necessary to "do homotopy theory" in C and model the homotopy category of C in which weak equivalences become isomorphisms. They are fundamental to contemporary homotopy theory and allied fields, but shockingly little is known about classification of model structures on a given category. We anticipate that the research and papers produced during the review period will open new vistas in the classification and enumeration of model structures.

In addition, Osorno complited research with collaborators on two separated projects. Joint with Gurski and Johsnon, she constructed a 2-categorical version of the S-1S construction of Quillen, thus providing a categorical version of the homotopical group completion for symmetric monoidal 2-categories. With Guillou, May and Merling, Osorno completed her long-term project of constructing a multiplicative equivariant infinite loop space machine whose input consists of certain equivariant categories. 

Broader Impacts

Two of our papers are coauthored with eCMRG undergraduate participants, and the mentorship provided during the research, writing, revision, and submission processes will help them pursue careers in research mathematics and allied fields.

The PIs also co-organized the Reed College Mathematics Teacher-Scholar Symposium (MaTSS) in May 2021. This two-day conference attracted 78 early-career participants deeply committed to advancing the goals of diversity, equity, and inclusion in the mathematical sciences, and helped prepare them for the job market.

Additionally, Ormsby led a virtual edition of the PCMI Undergraduate Faculty Program (UFP) in August 2021. This week-long workshop hosted eleven participants with a strong interest in undergraduate teaching and research. The UFP simultaneously introduced participants to open problems in motivic homotopy theory suitable for undergraduate research projects while leading group discussions on how to successfully lead such projects.

Finally, Osorno continued with her duties as one of the lead organizers of the 3rd edition of the Women in Topology workshop (during this period this entailed editorial work for the proceedings volume). She is also the lead organizer for the 4th edition.


Last Modified: 12/22/2021
Modified by: Angelica M Osorno
